title: About
text:
Maliik Jones
University of Nebraska-Lincoln Student

title: What Does it Take to be a Top 5 College Football Team Offensively
text:
Similar to the NCAA Basketball AP rankings, college football has their own top 25 ranked teams. I went and compared the top five squads from the 2023 preseason to the end of the season. Specifically looking at their offensive stats and how they differed. Breaking them down into two main categories of offense: passing and rushing. With sub-categories of passing percentage, passing yards, and passing touchdowns for passing the ball. Then rushing average, rushing yards, and rushing touchdowns for running the ball.
I believe that to stand out and be known as an elite squad you must excel on the offensive end of the ball. College football games tend to have high scoring results and which team can put the ball in the end-zone most efficiently will rise to the top.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(gt)

fball <- read_csv("footballlogs23.csv")


Rows: 1702 Columns: 54
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): HomeAway, Opponent, Result, TeamFull, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Con...
dbl  (45): Game, PassingCmp, PassingAtt, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD, ...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
pretop5pass <- fball |>
  filter(TeamFull=="Georgia Bulldogs"|
          TeamFull=="Michigan Wolverines"|
          TeamFull=="Ohio State Buckeyes"|
          TeamFull=="Alabama Crimson Tide"|
          TeamFull=="LSU Fighting Tigers"
         )|>
  select(TeamFull, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(
    TotalPassPct = sum(PassingPct)/12,
    TotalPassYds = sum(PassingYds),
    TotalPassTD = sum(PassingTD))

pretop5pass |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TeamFull = "Team",
    TotalPassPct = "Total Passing Percentage",
    TotalPassYds = "Total Passing Yards",
    TotalPassTD = "Total Passing Touchdowns"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "How well the 2023 preseason top 5 teams passed the football.",
    subtitle = "Both Ohio State and LSU fell out of the top 5 by the end of the season."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Maliik Jones  |  **Source:** College Football at Sports-Reference.com")
  )|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = TeamFull == "Ohio State Buckeyes"|
        TeamFull == "LSU Fighting Tigers")
  )








How well the 2023 preseason top 5 teams passed the football.


Both Ohio State and LSU fell out of the top 5 by the end of the season.


Team
Total Passing Percentage
Total Passing Yards
Total Passing Touchdowns




Alabama Crimson Tide
75.26667
3086
23


Georgia Bulldogs
83.42500
4274
29


LSU Fighting Tigers
75.25833
4406
44


Michigan Wolverines
89.91667
3205
24


Ohio State Buckeyes
69.10833
3498
26



By: Maliik Jones | Source: College Football at Sports-Reference.com








As you can see here passing percentage was a big factor comparing the three teams that stayed in the top 5 compared to LSU and Ohio State. Especially Ohio State having the most sub-par stats in every category. Maybe they just weren’t a passing football team… Let’s look at the rushing stats from these teams.


Code
pretop5rush <- fball |>
  filter(TeamFull=="Georgia Bulldogs"|
          TeamFull=="Michigan Wolverines"|
          TeamFull=="Ohio State Buckeyes"|
          TeamFull=="Alabama Crimson Tide"|
          TeamFull=="LSU Fighting Tigers"
         )|>
  select(TeamFull, RushingAvg, RushingYds, RushingTD) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(
    TotalRushAvg = sum(RushingAvg)/12,
    TotalRushYds = sum(RushingYds),
    TotalRushTD = sum(RushingTD))

pretop5rush |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TeamFull = "Team",
    TotalRushAvg = "Total Rushing Average",
    TotalRushYds = "Total Rushing Yards",
    TotalRushTD = "Total Rushing Touchdowns"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "How well the 2023 preseason top 5 teams rushed the football.",
    subtitle = "Both Ohio State and LSU fell out of the top 5 by the end of the season."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Maliik Jones  |  **Source:** College Football at Sports-Reference.com")
  )|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = TeamFull == "Ohio State Buckeyes"|
        TeamFull == "LSU Fighting Tigers")
  )








How well the 2023 preseason top 5 teams rushed the football.


Both Ohio State and LSU fell out of the top 5 by the end of the season.


Team
Total Rushing Average
Total Rushing Yards
Total Rushing Touchdowns




Alabama Crimson Tide
4.991667
2417
32


Georgia Bulldogs
6.091667
2677
40


LSU Fighting Tigers
6.708333
2659
34


Michigan Wolverines
5.608333
2536
40


Ohio State Buckeyes
4.591667
1805
20



By: Maliik Jones | Source: College Football at Sports-Reference.com








The rushing numbers tell pretty much the same story here. Ohio State falling under each team by a good amount. However, LSU actually did run the ball pretty well this season. Now, let’s look at the two teams that entered the top 5 in postseason.


Code
posttop5pass <- fball |>
  filter(TeamFull=="Texas Longhorns"|
          TeamFull=="Washington Huskies"
         )|>
  select(TeamFull, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(
    TotalPassPct = sum(PassingPct)/12,
    TotalPassYds = sum(PassingYds),
    TotalPassTD = sum(PassingTD))

posttop5pass |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TeamFull = "Team",
    TotalPassPct = "Total Passing Percentage",
    TotalPassYds = "Total Passing Yards",
    TotalPassTD = "Total Passing Touchdowns"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "How well the two teams that entered the 2023 postseason top 5 passed the football.",
    subtitle = "Specifically the Huskies excelled at getting the ball down the field through the air."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Maliik Jones  |  **Source:** College Football at Sports-Reference.com")
  )|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "green"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = TeamFull == "Washington Huskies"|
        TotalPassYds == "5155")
  )








How well the two teams that entered the 2023 postseason top 5 passed the football.


Specifically the Huskies excelled at getting the ball down the field through the air.


Team
Total Passing Percentage
Total Passing Yards
Total Passing Touchdowns




Texas Longhorns
77.50
4047
25


Washington Huskies
81.75
5155
38



By: Maliik Jones | Source: College Football at Sports-Reference.com








The Washington Huskies were big time threats in the air this season. Having the most passing yards out of any team listed. Also both of these teams completed passes at a very high level. Now, let’s take a peek at the rushing stats.


Code
posttop5rush <- fball |>
  filter(TeamFull=="Texas Longhorns"|
          TeamFull=="Washington Huskies"
         )|>
  select(TeamFull, RushingAvg, RushingYds, RushingTD) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(
    TotalRushAvg = sum(RushingAvg)/12,
    TotalRushYds = sum(RushingYds),
    TotalRushTD = sum(RushingTD))

posttop5rush |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TeamFull = "Team",
    TotalRushAvg = "Total Rushing Average",
    TotalRushYds = "Total Rushing Yards",
    TotalRushTD = "Total Rushing Touchdowns"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "How well the two teams that entered the 2023 postseason top 5 rushed the football.",
    subtitle = "The Longhorns excelled in getting those rushing yards throughout the season."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Maliik Jones  |  **Source:** College Football at Sports-Reference.com")
  )|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "green"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = TeamFull == "Texas Longhorns")
  )








How well the two teams that entered the 2023 postseason top 5 rushed the football.


The Longhorns excelled in getting those rushing yards throughout the season.


Team
Total Rushing Average
Total Rushing Yards
Total Rushing Touchdowns




Texas Longhorns
5.816667
2638
29


Washington Huskies
5.091667
1776
28



By: Maliik Jones | Source: College Football at Sports-Reference.com








The Longhorns did great when it came to the ground game and even though the Huskies didn’t rely on running as much, they clearly found their strong suit in the passing game. When they did run they still were able to average 5 yards per carry which is higher than Alabama’s run game.
The offensive game at a high level is insane, I mean Michigan and Georgia had 80+ passing completion percentage. As well as being able to average around 6 yards per carry on the ground. It’s like these top teams are completely unstoppable on this end of the ball.

title: How the 2023-24 College Basketball Preseason Rankings Turned Out
text:
The AP top 25 polls come in each week of the NCAA Basketball season. These are the compiled pollings from sportswriters and broadcasters all around the country. So, just how accurate are these rankings from the start of the season to the end.
I took a look at the stats from the top five basketball teams from the preseason and then compared them to the stats of the final top five teams. Obviously, I’m not going to look at each and every category so I summed up defense into steals, blocks, and rebounds. Then I summed up offense into field goal percentage, three point percentage, and assist to turnover ratio.
Personally, I believe that these are purely guesses and it’s not possible to KNOW who’s going to be a top caliber team. Maybe you can tell if a team will win most of their games, but winning at a high level? College basketball has way too many factors and underdogs to truly know.
Also I wonder what really defines these teams and makes them top five in the country…
Let’s peek at the preseason stats first:


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(gt)

bball <- read_csv("logs24.csv")


Rows: 11907 Columns: 48
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): Season, TeamFull, Opponent, HomeAway, W_L, URL, Conference, Team
dbl  (39): Game, TeamScore, OpponentScore, TeamFG, TeamFGA, TeamFGPCT, Team3...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
pretop5def <- bball |>
  filter(TeamFull=="Duke Blue Devils" |
         TeamFull=="Kansas Jayhawks" |
         TeamFull=="Marquette Golden Eagles" |
         TeamFull=="Michigan State Spartans" |
         TeamFull=="Purdue Boilermakers") |>
  select(TeamFull, TeamSteals, TeamBlocks, TeamTotalRebounds) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(
    TotalSteals = sum(TeamSteals),
    TotalBlocks = sum(TeamBlocks),
    TotalRebounds = sum(TeamTotalRebounds))

pretop5def |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TeamFull = "Team",
    TotalSteals = "Total Team Steals",
    TotalBlocks = "Total Team Blocks",
    TotalRebounds = "Total Team Rebounds"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "How the preseason top 5 teams competed on defense.",
    subtitle = "Purdue was the only team to stay top 5 and they led in blocks & rebounds."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Maliik Jones  |  **Source:** College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com: AP Polls")
  )|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "green"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = TeamFull == "Purdue Boilermakers")
  )








How the preseason top 5 teams competed on defense.


Purdue was the only team to stay top 5 and they led in blocks & rebounds.


Team
Total Team Steals
Total Team Blocks
Total Team Rebounds




Duke Blue Devils
227
127
1145


Kansas Jayhawks
243
133
1116


Marquette Golden Eagles
310
125
1087


Michigan State Spartans
248
132
1112


Purdue Boilermakers
196
135
1335



By: Maliik Jones | Source: College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com: AP Polls








Here you can see that Purdue is a standout team compared to the other four. Purdue was also the only team to stay in the top five at the end of the season.
Now, let’s look at the offense:


Code
pretop5off <- bball |>
  filter(TeamFull=="Duke Blue Devils" |
         TeamFull=="Kansas Jayhawks" |
         TeamFull=="Marquette Golden Eagles" |
         TeamFull=="Michigan State Spartans" |
         TeamFull=="Purdue Boilermakers") |>
  select(TeamFull, TeamFG, TeamFGA, Team3P, Team3PA, TeamAssists, TeamTurnovers) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(
    TotalFG = sum(TeamFG),
    TotalFGA = sum(TeamFGA),
    Total3P = sum(Team3P),
    Total3PA = sum(Team3PA),
    TotalAst = sum(TeamAssists),
    TotalTurnovers = sum(TeamTurnovers))|>
  mutate(FGPct = TotalFG/TotalFGA, ThreePct = Total3P/Total3PA, AstTO = TotalAst/TotalTurnovers) |>
  select(TeamFull, FGPct, ThreePct, AstTO)

pretop5off |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TeamFull = "Team",
    FGPct = "Total Field Goal Percentage",
    ThreePct = "Total Three Point Percentage",
    AstTO = "Assist/Turnover Ratio"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "How the preseason top 5 teams performed offensively throughout the season.",
    subtitle = "Purdue was the only team to stay top 5 and they led in all categories."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Maliik Jones  |  **Source:** College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com: AP Polls")
  )|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "green"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = TeamFull == "Purdue Boilermakers")
  )








How the preseason top 5 teams performed offensively throughout the season.


Purdue was the only team to stay top 5 and they led in all categories.


Team
Total Field Goal Percentage
Total Three Point Percentage
Assist/Turnover Ratio




Duke Blue Devils
0.4815369
0.3806366
1.669841


Kansas Jayhawks
0.4880529
0.3321976
1.671835


Marquette Golden Eagles
0.4817851
0.3600892
1.644886


Michigan State Spartans
0.4611273
0.3626198
1.685801


Purdue Boilermakers
0.4902629
0.4091540
1.729659



By: Maliik Jones | Source: College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com: AP Polls








As you can see from the offensive side Purdue still stands out compared to the other four teams.
Now, let’s take a look at the teams who ended up in the top five after the season was over:


Code
posttop5def <- bball |>
  filter(TeamFull=="Alabama Crimson Tide" |
         TeamFull=="Houston Cougars" |
         TeamFull=="UConn Huskies" |
         TeamFull=="Purdue Boilermakers" |
         TeamFull=="Tennessee Volunteers") |>
  select(TeamFull, TeamSteals, TeamBlocks, TeamTotalRebounds) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(
    TotalSteals = sum(TeamSteals),
    TotalBlocks = sum(TeamBlocks),
    TotalRebounds = sum(TeamTotalRebounds))

posttop5def |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TeamFull = "Team",
    TotalSteals = "Total Team Steals",
    TotalBlocks = "Total Team Blocks",
    TotalRebounds = "Total Team Rebounds"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "How the post-season top 5 teams competed on defense.",
    subtitle = "All five of these teams ended up performing at a higher level than the predicted top 5 teams."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Maliik Jones  |  **Source:** College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com: AP Polls")
  )








How the post-season top 5 teams competed on defense.


All five of these teams ended up performing at a higher level than the predicted top 5 teams.


Team
Total Team Steals
Total Team Blocks
Total Team Rebounds




Alabama Crimson Tide
247
144
1229


Houston Cougars
358
174
1243


Purdue Boilermakers
196
135
1335


Tennessee Volunteers
267
157
1234


UConn Huskies
224
194
1273



By: Maliik Jones | Source: College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com: AP Polls








Defensively, these five teams all did statistically better than the predicted top five teams in preseason.
Now, let’s look at the offense:


Code
posttop5off <- bball |>
  filter(TeamFull=="Alabama Crimson Tide" |
         TeamFull=="Houston Cougars" |
         TeamFull=="Purdue Boilermakers" |
         TeamFull=="Tennessee Volunteers" |
         TeamFull=="UConn Huskies") |>
  select(TeamFull, TeamFG, TeamFGA, Team3P, Team3PA, TeamAssists, TeamTurnovers) |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarize(
    TotalFG = sum(TeamFG),
    TotalFGA = sum(TeamFGA),
    Total3P = sum(Team3P),
    Total3PA = sum(Team3PA),
    TotalAst = sum(TeamAssists),
    TotalTurnovers = sum(TeamTurnovers))|>
  mutate(FGPct = TotalFG/TotalFGA, ThreePct = Total3P/Total3PA, AstTO = TotalAst/TotalTurnovers) |>
  select(TeamFull, FGPct, ThreePct, AstTO)

posttop5off |> 
  gt() |> 
  cols_label(
    TeamFull = "Team",
    FGPct = "Total Field Goal Percentage",
    ThreePct = "Total Three Point Percentage",
    AstTO = "Assist/Turnover Ratio"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "How the post-season top 5 teams performed offensively throughout the season.",
    subtitle = "Their offensive stats were pretty similar compared to the preseason top 5 teams."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Maliik Jones  |  **Source:** College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com: AP Polls")
  )








How the post-season top 5 teams performed offensively throughout the season.


Their offensive stats were pretty similar compared to the preseason top 5 teams.


Team
Total Field Goal Percentage
Total Three Point Percentage
Assist/Turnover Ratio




Alabama Crimson Tide
0.4772520
0.3665689
1.362500


Houston Cougars
0.4400183
0.3493235
1.569536


Purdue Boilermakers
0.4902629
0.4091540
1.729659


Tennessee Volunteers
0.4426934
0.3387283
1.638728


UConn Huskies
0.4981114
0.3612079
2.074074



By: Maliik Jones | Source: College Basketball at Sports-Reference.com: AP Polls








While, offensively these teams were pretty similar in stats to the top five teams in the preseason. So, is defense the big factor to build a real top five caliber squad? I guess it really does win games and championships as UConn went on to win it all last season.
I also found it interesting that Purdue was the only team to stay in the top five from start to finish. Like I said, knowing who’s going to be the cream of the crop cannot be predicted perfectly.

title: MaliiksSportsBlog
text:
